input:
2. A 45-year-old man comes to the endocrinology clinic complaining of decreased libido and erectile dysfunction over the past year. He also notes progressive fatigue and occasional headaches localized to the frontal region. His wife has noticed mild galactorrhea, which he had not initially reported. On examination, there is no significant visual field deficit, but mild bitemporal upper quadrant loss is detected on detailed perimetry. Blood tests reveal elevated serum prolactin levels at 250 ng/mL, and testosterone is low. An MRI scan identifies a 2.2 cm pituitary macroadenoma without cavernous sinus invasion. The patient denies medications or thyroid disease that might account for hyperprolactinemia. He is started on cabergoline and scheduled for follow-up hormone monitoring and visual field assessment.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient should mention the main symptoms that brought him to the clinic but in a way that reflects his confusion and feelings of uncertainty. He shouldn't overthink what to say but should honestly explain what he's experiencing.

ANSWER: I’m 45, and I’ve been feeling really tired all the time, like I don’t have much energy, and I’ve noticed I don’t feel interested in things anymore. My wife said I’ve been leaking some milk-like stuff, and I’ve been having some headaches that come and go. It sort of just all snuck up on me, and I guess I wanted to see what’s going on.

input: 2. A 45-year-old man comes to the endocrinology clinic complaining of decreased libido and erectile dysfunction over the past year. He also notes progressive fatigue and occasional headaches localized to the frontal region. His wife has noticed mild galactorrhea, which he had not initially reported. On examination, there is no significant visual field deficit, but mild bitemporal upper quadrant loss is detected on detailed perimetry. Blood tests reveal elevated serum prolactin levels at 250 ng/mL, and testosterone is low. An MRI scan identifies a 2.2 cm pituitary macroadenoma without cavernous sinus invasion. The patient denies medications or thyroid disease that might account for hyperprolactinemia. He is started on cabergoline and scheduled for follow-up hormone monitoring and visual field assessment.Can you tell me more about when your symptoms started, how they've been affecting your daily life, and if you've noticed any other changes or concerns recently?
output: Well, um, it started maybe about a year ago, I think? Things just started feeling off—less interested in stuff I used to enjoy, and I guess I’ve been really tired, like always. Sometimes I get headaches, especially in the front, and I’ve noticed my wife mentioning stuff about milk coming out, which I didn’t think much of at first. It’s making things kinda hard at work and around the house. I’m kind of worried about it all, but I don’t really understand what’s going on.

He is started on cabergoline and scheduled for follow-up hormone monitoring and visual field assessment.Can you tell me more about how these symptoms have been affecting your daily life and if there are any other concerns or changes you've noticed recently?
output: I guess I’ve been feeling pretty tired all the time, even when I sleep enough. Sometimes I just don’t feel like doing much, and I’ve noticed I don’t have the same energy I used to. It’s also kind of annoying because my head hurts sometimes, and I’ve been a bit worried about what all this means.

He is started on cabergoline and scheduled for follow-up hormone monitoring and visual field assessment.Can you tell me more about how you've been feeling overall lately, any changes you've noticed in your mood, energy levels, or physical health, and how these symptoms have affected your daily routines?
output: Um, I've just been feeling kind of more tired than usual, like I don't have much energy, and I sometimes get these headaches — especially in the front. I don't really feel like myself, and everything feels a bit heavier or harder to do. My mood's been a little up and down, and it's affecting how I go about my day, I guess.

output: Um, well, I guess I have noticed some weird feelings in my head, like a little pressure sometimes, but I didn't really think it was anything. My vision feels kind of funny now and then, especially on the sides, like it's harder to see out of the corners. And the headaches, they're there but not super strong, just kind of nagging.

input: 2. A 45-year-old man comes to the endocrinology clinic complaining of decreased libido and erectile dysfunction over the past year. He also notes progressive fatigue and occasional headaches localized to the frontal region. His wife has noticed mild galactorrhea, which he had not initially reported. Blood tests reveal elevated serum prolactin levels at 250 ng/mL, and testosterone is low. An MRI scan identifies a 2.2 cm pituitary macroadenoma without cavernous sinus invasion. output: Um, I think the headaches have kind of come and gone, but lately, I feel a bit more like I see things a little differently, especially when I look to the sides. It’s not constant, but it’s there sometimes.
